courseTitle: Introduction to Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies
courseDescription: An introduction to the interdisciplinary field of Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies, drawing on materials from the humanities and social sciences. Topics include the social construction of gender, cross-cultural variations in women's lives, media representations, work, health, women's roles in politics and sexuality.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective discussion of gender and sexuality topics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of gender roles in politics

courseTitle: Honors: Gender and Sexuality in a Changing World
courseDescription: A special honors version of WGSÂ 201S open only to students in the Honors College.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and analyzing historical and contemporary gender issues
Applying interdisciplinary perspectives to gender and sexuality

courseDescription: This course is designed to develop students' skills in writing, critical reading, research, and argument while examining topics in Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies. The course also covers the history of Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies as a discipline and current opportunities for majors and minors.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpretation and analysis of academic texts

courseTitle: Dimensions of Diversity: Intersectionality Among Women
courseDescription: This course explores the intersections of gender, race, class, and sexuality within society; it examines how identity has been a key site for generating knowledge and political action. Students will learn the histories and nuances of topics such as intersectionality, privilege, allyship, and cultural appropriation. Finally, the course will examine how concepts such as 'diversity' are mobilized in relation to different institutions, such as the law and education. This is a writing intensive course.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and applying principles of allyship

courseDescription: This course is an interdisciplinary study of LGBTQ+ (lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer) experiences. It introduces students to personal, cultural, and political aspects of queer life while examining social forces such as heteronormativity, the social construction of gender, and homophobia and their impact on queer lives.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and empathy towards diverse sexual orientations and gender identities
Effective communication with people of diverse identities
Advocacy for LGBTQ+ rights and issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of social constructs like heteronormativity
Critically evaluating societal attitudes towards LGBTQ+ community
Understanding and assessing the impact of homophobia on queer lives

courseDescription: This course introduces students to feminist methods of analyzing media, with a focus on gender and sexuality in film. Key questions include: How do films influence and reflect our social locations? What are the points that they raise about the intersections of gender, race, and sexuality? Students will interrogate if, and in what ways, film can be a tool to effect social change.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Articulating informed perspectives on gender and sexuality

courseDescription: This course provides a historical sampling of queer literary voices in the U.S. Students explore fiction, poetry, drama, and visual literary forms through the lens of queer theory. Students investigate the ways in which queer authors and subjects have been excluded from the traditional canon and how readers, academics, critics, and authors of anthologies have ignored or obscured queer possibilities and homoeroticism in literary works. Students also explore the benefits of thinking of queer literary works as queer literatures (in the plural sense rather than the singular Queer Literature) and attempt to answer the question, is there such a thing as Queer Literature?
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of exclusionary practices in literature

courseTitle: Women, the Environment, and Climate Change
courseDescription: This course will examine ways that women have been actively involved in environmental issues from earliest history through today. Students will assess their own connection to place and examine and access ecofeminist theory and national and global environmental justice movements, along with briefly reviewing gender and farming practices. Finally, the course will examine how climate change issues are affecting lives around the globe, including ours, and question how gender-, race-, and class-sensitive responses to the environmental challenges facing our planet can be created.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research and analysis of environmental justice movements
Understanding gender-, race-, and class-sensitive responses to environmental challenges
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussing and interpreting gender and environmental issues
Assessing personal connection to environmental issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of climate change on global communities
Evaluating the role of women in environmental history
Understanding environmental challenges from diverse perspectives
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on ecofeminist theory and environmental justice movements
Developing gender-, race-, and class-sensitive responses to environmental challenges

courseDescription: This course provides an opportunity to gain experience working in organizations and government agencies. Students' work should engage with women's issues at the local, regional, national, and/or global levels. Students must work for at least 50 hours per course credit.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of women's issues at various levels
Development of strategic responses to women's issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in a nonprofit or government setting

courseDescription: An exploration of women as designers and users of technology and of the impact of technology on women's lives across the world. Variations in women's experiences by race, class, culture, and sexuality will be stressed, along with particular focus on global developments that shape the context of people's lives.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of societal and cultural impacts of technology

courseTitle: Topics in Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies
courseDescription: A study of selected topics in Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies. These courses are usually interdisciplinary and align with faculty teaching and research strengths.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of gender and sexuality issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and synthesizing complex social issues

courseTitle: Topics in Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies
courseDescription: A study of selected topics in Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies. These courses are usually interdisciplinary and align with faculty teaching and research strengths.

This course historicizes U.S. women's social, political, and rhetorical activism over the last 200 years, tracing their entry into and shaping force upon public life. The course examines the development of women's activism in the nineteenth century, the twentieth century women's (or feminist) movement, and its current status, particularly in relation to postfeminism and a 'third' wave.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of social and political trends

courseDescription: An analysis of the global forces that impact women's lives throughout the world. Particular emphasis is placed on the status of women in the developing world, international institutions that protect women's rights, and efforts to promote gender equality worldwide. This is a writing intensive course.

This course will examine feminist approaches to the subject of sexuality in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. The course examines theorizations of sexuality, such as radical, critical race, and transnational feminisms, queer theory, and trans studies. Key questions will be: how have feminists theorized sexualities? What does sexuality have to do with feminist studies or practices? How do other identities, such as race and class, inform sexuality?
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and applying queer theory and trans studies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and presenting complex theoretical concepts

courseDescription: This course examines media-based sites of knowledge production using a feminist approach, in order to imagine new and more complex ways to think about media rhetorics; celebrity culture; digital media; and the politics of representation. Key questions will be: What roles do media play in shaping social movements? What are the promises and pitfalls of activist interventions in the realm of commercial culture? In what ways might we complicate narratives of co-optation or selling out? The class explores these questions using an intersectional lens attentive to the complex interconnections of race, class, gender, and sexuality. Case studies will include national, international, and transnational media events.
Technical and Digital Skills: Evaluation of commercial culture's digital footprint
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of media influence on social movements
Analysis of national, international and transnational media events
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of activist interventions in commercial culture
Leadership in imagining complex media perspectives

courseDescription: This interdisciplinary class explores the body as a canvas for both history and the future of our concept of individualism. Students will have the opportunity to reflect not only on their own understanding of the body but also that of the body across a variety of experiences. Students will complete auto-ethnographic essays and a course paper on the body relating to her/his/their academic research interests.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpretation of historical and contemporary body concepts

courseDescription: This course will explore the spectrum of what it means when we consider humans to exist in a gendered and sexed world. Students will critique their own preconceived notions of sex, probe issues of equality and social justice, and discuss what these questions mean both in the United States and globally. The course will culminate with a restructuring of how we understand the ways in which we define sex, sexuality, and sexual practice, taking into consideration how our own identities are impacted by culture and society.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discourse and discussion on sensitive topics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing societal and cultural impacts on identity
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions about gender and sexuality

courseDescription: This course explores the international context of refugees and migrants from a humanitarian perspective.  Global conditions that lead to forced migration are analyzed to inform a larger understanding of human displacement. The course works directly with refugee resettlement organizations at the national and local levels.
Technical and Digital Skills: utilizing digital tools for communication and coordination with resettlement organizations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: negotiation and liaison with resettlement organizations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of global conditions leading to forced migration
understanding and addressing challenges in refugee resettlement
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordination with local and national organizations

courseDescription: This course will examine feminist and queer theories, specifically intersectional, transnational, and radical perspectives. It explores how feminist and queer scholars approach research, writing, and knowledge production, and applies these insights to students' own interests. The course analyzes how feminist and queer scholars have written about storytelling, the body, and desire, and links these discussions to how to produce positive social change in our world. This course is fundamentally interdisciplinary; students are encouraged to make connections between the course materials, their research interests, and other fields of study. This is a writing intensive course.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Researching and conveying intersectional, transnational, and radical perspectives
Discussing storytelling, the body, and desire
Communicating ideas for positive social change
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying feminist and queer theories to research
Identifying connections between course materials, research interests, and other fields of study

courseDescription: The course explores the ethics, practice, and multiple forms of conducting feminist research. Narrative research methods are practiced through hands-on oral herstory assignments. Throughout the course, the process of knowledge construction is interrogated from a feminist perspective.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Sharing and interpreting narrative research findings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of research methods from a feminist perspective

courseTitle: Topics in Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies
courseDescription: Advanced seminars on selected topics. The subject matter is usually interdisciplinary and aligns with faculty teaching and research strengths.

courseTitle: Topics in Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies
courseDescription: Advanced seminars on selected topics. The subject matter is usually interdisciplinary and aligns with faculty teaching and research strengths.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of gender and sexuality research

courseDescription: Independent study of an interdisciplinary topic in Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies, or a reading plus internship project to be selected under the direction of a faculty member. Conferences and papers as appropriate.

Independent study of an interdisciplinary topic in Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies, or a reading plus internship project to be selected under the direction of a faculty member. Conferences and papers as appropriate.

This course historicizes U.S. women's social, political, and rhetorical activism over the last 200 years, tracing their entry into and shaping force upon public life. The course examines the development of women's activism in the nineteenth century, the twentieth-century women's (or feminist) movement, and its current status, particularly in relation to postfeminism and a 'third' wave.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of social movements and leadership

courseDescription: An analysis of the global forces that impact women's lives throughout the world. Particular emphasis is placed on the status of women in the developing world, international institutions that protect women's rights, and efforts to promote gender equality worldwide.
Technical and Digital Skills: Digital literacy for understanding and accessing global data
Use of digital tools for data analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing global data on gender equality
Critical thinking on social and cultural issues
Problem-solving in the context of gender equality
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing information on global gender issues
Leadership in advocating for gender equality

courseDescription: This course will examine feminist approaches to the subject of sexuality in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. The course examines theorizations of sexuality, such as radical, critical race, and transnational feminisms, queer theory, and trans studies. Key questions will be: how have feminists theorized sexualities? What does sexuality have to do with feminist studies or practices? How do other identities, such as race and class, inform sexuality?
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving within the context of feminist theory

courseDescription: This course examines media-based sites of knowledge production using a feminist approach, in order to imagine new and more complex ways to think about media rhetorics; celebrity culture; digital media; and the politics of representation. Key questions will be: What roles do media play in shaping social movements? What are the promises and pitfalls of activist interventions in the realm of commercial culture? In what ways might we complicate narratives of co-optation or selling out? The course explores these questions using an intersectional lens attentive to the complex interconnections of race, class, gender, and sexuality. Case studies will include national, international, and transnational media events.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of media-based sites of knowledge production
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpretation and communication of celebrity culture
Comprehension and explanation of representation politics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and evaluation of media's role in social movements
Critical scrutiny of activist interventions in commercial culture
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Application of intersectional lens in media analysis
Organizing and carrying out case studies on media events

Students will have the opportunity to reflect not only on their own understanding of the body but also that of the body across a variety of experiences. Students will complete auto-ethnographic essays and a course paper on the body relating to her/his/their academic research interests.

Global conditions that lead to forced migration are analyzed to inform a larger understanding of human displacement. The course works directly with refugee resettlement organizations at the national and local levels.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis for global migration conditions
Working with digital tools for refugee resettlement
Understanding international humanitarian laws and principles
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing causes and effects of forced migration
Critical evaluation of global conditions leading to displacement
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and planning in collaboration with local and national organizations

courseTitle: Topics in Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies
courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics which permit small groups of qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest under the direction on an instructor. Courses may not be offered regularly; when offered courses appear in the course schedule and are more fully described in information distributed to advisors.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and utilizing relevant databases and online resources
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in small group settings

courseDescription: Independent study of an interdisciplinary women's studies topics to be selected under the direction of a women's studies faculty member. Conferences and papers as appropriate.
Independent study of an interdisciplinary women's studies topics to be selected under the direction of a women's studies faculty member. Conferences and papers as appropriate.

This seminar course explores the international context of refugees and migrants from a humanitarian perspective.  Global conditions that lead to forced migration are analyzed to inform a larger understanding of human displacement. Through analysis at the community, national, and international levels, participants will gain both in-depth content on this contemporary human rights topic and tools for application in a number of fields.
